chapter.title: Introduction to Statistics and Descriptive Statistics

introduction.p:
The learning objectives for this chapter are:
To understand how data collection methods differ and how they affect the nature of the data set.
To understand and be able to evaluate different design studies.
To understand and be able to analyze data using appropriate graphs and tables.
To understand how graphs and tables of data can sometimes be misleading.

statement.p:
Lily Robinson is running for the U.S. Senate in Utah. In a poll of 1,400 voters, 428 voters support her.
What is the population for this poll?
If P people vote in the election, what is a good prediction of the number that will vote for Ms.Robinson?

A survey of shoppers shows that 20 prefer whole milk, 42 prefer low-fat milk, 28 prefer skim milk, and 10 prefer soy milk.
If 600 shoppers come to the store tomorrow, predict how many will buy each kind of milk.
Explain how you made your prediction.

Classify each of the following as simple random sampling, stratified sampling, or convenience sampling.
A student newspaper selects 10 names at random from the entire student body.
A student newspaper interviews proportional numbers of freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors.
A researcher interviews all AIDS patients in the hospital closest to the researcher's home.

Describe how to take a sample of 30 high school seniors from 300 high school seniors using
a simple random sample.
stratified sampling.
voluntary response sampling.

A sample of 50 people is obtained to rate Frosted-Chocolate Sugar Bombs, a breakfast cereal. Tell whether each of the following is an example of undercoverage, nonresponse, or response bias.
An interviewer visits a randomly selected set of homes and asks the first 50 people who answer the door whether they eat Frosted-Chocolate Sugar Bombs for breakfast.
An interviewer goes to the local Whole Paycheck Food Market and observes what breakfast foods 50 shoppers select.
A school finds that 75 of the students in detention are boys even though only 45 of the students are boys. Does this show that the school is biased against boys? Tell why or why not.

Tell whether each of the following is an observational study or an experiment.
A researcher randomly assigns 30 people to a statistics class using the lecture method and 30 students to an online statistics class. Their average scores on the final exam are compared.
A researcher finds 50 people who are overweight and 50 who are not. She compares the average number of hours they spend each week watching television.

section.title: Analyzing Data with Graphs and Tables

statement.p: The following data set is the number of home runs that Babe Ruth hit during his 15-year career in major league baseball.

ol.li: Draw a dot plot on the number of home runs that Babe Ruth hit during is career.
Draw a stem-and-leaf plot of Ruth's home runs.

statement.p: The following data is the number of home runs that Barry Bonds hit during his major league career.

ol.li: Draw back-to-back stem-and-leaf plots of Bond's and Ruth's home runs.
Who was the better home run hitter during his career?

statement.p: Table shows the grade distribution for the final examination in a statistics course. Draw an appropriate graph for the data.

table.caption: Final Exam Grades for a Statistics Course

statement.p: A cheetah can run 70 mph, a lion can run 50 mph, and grizzly bear can run 30 mph, and a human can run 28 mph. Draw an appropriate graph to represent this data set.

The 1918 flu pandemic (commonly referred to as the Spanish flu) was an influenza pandemic that spread to nearly every part of the world. The Spanish flu lasted from March 1918 to June 1920. It is estimated that anywhere from 20 to 100 million people were killed worldwide. The data on the number of new influenza cases and the number of deaths from the epidemic in San Francisco week by week from October 5, 1918 to January 25, 1919 is given in Table. The data is given on the last day of the week.
Make a line graph of weekly new cases. Based on your plot, describe the progress of the epidemic.
We would like to compare the patterns over time of the number of new cases with the number of deaths. To make the new variables similar in size for easier comparison, plot the number of deaths against time for October 5 to January 25, then plot the number of cases divided by 10 on the same graph using a different color. What do you see? In particular, how long is the lag between the changes in the number of cases and corresponding changes in deaths?
Why was the 1918 flu epidemic called the Spanish flu?

For each of the following data sets, determine whether the best choice to represent the data graphically is a line graph, a bar graph, or a circle graph (pie chart).
The average trade-in value of a 2000 Honda Civic for the years 20002014 as a percentage of the original purchase price of the car.
Car sales by percentage of vehicle type (small, midsize, large, and luxury) in 2011.
The lengths of selected rivers in the U.S. (Arkansas, Columbia, Mississippi, Missouri, Ohio, and Yukon).
